## Search Results Summary

### Digital Humanities Analysis

Recent digital humanities work includes a 2021 study in Digital Scholarship in the Humanities by Rachel McCarthy and James O'Sullivan titled "Who wrote Wuthering Heights?" which used stylometry to examine authorship questions. The study demonstrated that "it is highly unlikely that Branwell" Brontë wrote the novel, addressing Victorian attitudes that questioned Emily Brontë's legitimacy as the sole author.(no content)A 2022 study in Scientific Programming examined "the Influence of Wuthering Heights Characters Based on Web Analysis and Text Mining," focusing on character relationships and thematic analysis through computational methods.

### Feminist and Queer Criticism

A significant 2021 essay in Brontë Studies explored "The Queer Ecological Aesthetics of Wuthering Heights," examining how Andrea Arnold's 2011 film adaptation "combines queer, ecofeminist and postcolonial approaches to disavow the institutional and cultural ways in which white heterosexist patriarchy 'sexualizes' nature and 'naturalizes' heterosexuality."(no content)Earlier feminist scholarship by Patsy Stoneman traced "feminist readings of the novel, dissecting how the book manages to encompass the universal within the domestic."

### Postcolonial and Race-Based Criticism

The search revealed extensive recent scholarship on race in Wuthering Heights:

A postcolonial reading titled "Can the Subaltern Speak? Color and Silence in Wuthering Heights" provided "a sharp critique of the contribution the novel makes to contemporary stereotypes and preconceptions of 'race' and culture," viewing Heathcliff's "otherness" as central to interpreting the novel.(no content)Recent scholarship by AnnaKate Burleson examined "Race and its Impact in Wuthering Heights," analyzing both Brontë's novel and Andrea Arnold's 2011 film adaptation, which "was a breakthrough because it was the first to depict Heathcliff as black."(no content)Contemporary pedagogical approaches include syllabi that examine "legacies of white supremacy in Victorian texts through the framework of Black studies, Black feminism, and postcolonial theory," pairing Wuthering Heights with Caryl Phillips's The Lost Child (2015) to investigate "the history of the Black Atlantic."

### Contemporary Critical Perspectives

A 2020 essay in the Journal of Victorian Culture argued for viewing Emily Brontë as "writing a radical novel," noting that the focus on romance "overlooks Brontë's depiction of the strangulating effect on Wuthering Heights's Catherine Earnshaw as she transforms from a brash child to a woman enmeshed within the patriarchy's physical and mental violence."(no content)A 2023 study in Research in Education used Wuthering Heights "as an interrogative framework" to examine educational exclusion, demonstrating how "fiction illuminates the human story and human issues in ways other discourses cannot."

### Ecocriticism

Recent ecocritical scholarship examined Wuthering Heights from environmental perspectives, arguing that "studying literary work is one way that can be taken to overcome environmental problems" and that "literary texts contain contents of ecological consciousness."

The contemporary scholarship demonstrates that Wuthering Heights continues to be a vital text for 2020s academic inquiry, with particular strength in digital humanities methods, intersectional feminist analysis, postcolonial race theory, and interdisciplinary approaches that connect the novel to contemporary social issues.
